content: Career Asked by Charmaine Lim XiaomeiAsked on 31 Oct 2018Do I need a licence to sell home-made goods (food / drinks) online in Singapore?3 answersAnswerBump2
Answers (3)Sort By Most UpvoteMost UpvoteMost Recent

Junus EuTop Contributor (Sep)Level 8. WizardAnswered on 26 May 2019No, BUT hygiene is paramount for all F&B related enterprises. Even though home-based food and drink sellers are not required to apply for a licence to sell their food/drinks, they should follow the food hygiene guidelines issued by the National Environment Agency (NEA).As we know, food outlets in Singapore are subject to the A-D rating for overall hygiene in food preparation and also upkeep of store. As a home-based food business, you won't be subject to the A-D grading system. But we would want to avoid customers falling ill after consuming such goods if the goods were not hygienically prepared.0 comments2

Cedric Jamie Soh, Director at Seniorcare.com.sgTop Contributor (Sep)Level 7. Grand MasterAnswered on 10 Jun 2019Yes. The rules are not so clear now as there are many home cook bloggers that cook small amount of food for sales, but generally if you are selling a decent amount of food or drink, it is better you check with the Food Safety Agency and get properly certified and trained to reduce any issue with the law.0 comments1

Kenneth Lou, Co-founder at SeedlyLevel 8. WizardAnswered on 01 Nov 2018I think no need? There are a ton of mom-pop shops on Carousell. Also, during Christmas and CNY, I actually help my fiance√©'s family make biscuits to sell to other friends and family.If not large scale should be ok. Also, unless you bring imports or set up distribution channels. My family wanted to import coconut oil from some SEA country before but in the end did not go ahead with it. They needed to go through the NEA certification and courses to do this haha.0 comments1
